entry.title: Combined summary - Random order for clients page
entry.summary: In 2012, developers on the Bitcoin.org wiki page engaged in a conversation about the listing of multiple Bitcoin clients. Jim expressed his satisfaction with the original layout and randomization of entries, while Amir Taaki proposed removing the page and suggested voting for it. However, Luke responded that he authored the page and it had significant traffic.The discussion then moved on to comparing different Bitcoin clients, including MultiBit, Armory, and Electrum, highlighting their respective features and benefits. Alan Reiner suggested adding a feature matrix to the wiki page, but others discouraged this idea as it may not be objective or useful for decision-making.The conversation touched upon the importance of neutrality, consensus, and community memory for the Bitcoin ecosystem. The use of tables in Bitcoin clients was also discussed, with concerns raised about biased development motivations towards features that make nice bullets, even if they are seldom used. This could lead to important infrastructure being neglected in favor of flashy features.Matrices were also criticized for making bad decision-making fast and attractive over careful decision-making that takes time. The text was deemed helpful in contextualizing the complete feature set and understanding why different clients exist, what problems they attempt to solve, and what compromises they make.Regarding the JS randomization, it was noted that it may cause disputes among users. It was agreed that the reference client should be the option that is led with since none of the primary alternatives are yet complete, and network health is vital. There are subtle distinctions between multiple kinds of clients in terms of security and network health that can be difficult to explain even to technical users.Finally, the cost of dealing with the Bitcoin clients page was starting to exceed the benefit it provides, and it was suggested that it should probably be removed.
